div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was an exceptionally fine day. To-day, too, the morning opens bright and clear, with a light S.E. breeze and a falling barometer. The humidity has increased and we may have more wind during the night. The total rainfall since the beginning of the season up to date amounts to 8.92 inches, as compared with 6.44 in. during last season.

div.head: EGYPT & THE NEW GOVERNMENT.
div.p: In our article on Monday we dealt with one of the two important announcements which Lord Cromer made in his speech at Port Sudan. In this article we propose to consider his Lordship's declaration that "both the general and local policy of the British Government in Egypt and the Sudan... will be found... wholly independent of ministerial changes in Egypt." This announcement was evidently due to the fact that there have been certain indications, of late, which we have noted, that hopes seem to be entertained that with the change of Government in England from Imperialist to Liberal a new policy may be inaugurated in Egypt. Is it of course difficult to forecast the exact lines on which the foreign policy of a Government which has only been in office for a few days will be based. It would be therefore premature to speak on the subject with anything like certainty. It is a wise counsel of a great Liberal politician not long deceased, Sir William Harcourt, who had had considerable experience in party manipulation, never to prophecy unless you know, and from that salutary rule we do not feel it incumbant on us to depart. Nevertheless it is permissible to hazard a conjecture, founded upon an examination of the actual situation. Now what is it that the Liberals might be asked to do which they with reasonable safety could accede to? Let us proceed by a process of elimination. They might be asked, but they would hardly agree to evacuation pure and simple, nor are they likely, under the present circumstances, and bearing in mind the recent Anglo-French Agreement, to call a conference of the Powers with a view to the neutralisation of Egypt under any conditions whatsoever. There remains only the question of Egypt's internal policy, or, in other words, the introduction of domestic reforms. Are there, then, candidly and dispassionately speaking, any valid grounds for interference by the Home Government? No one who knows Egypt well would pretend to say that there is no room for amelioration in the present Administration, and least of all Lord Cromer himself For not only is he equally pointing out with persistency other directions in which changes for the better might be adopted. Of course there will always be in every country a certain number of malcontents, who seem to gain a cheap popularity by manufacturing grievances and harping on imaginary abuses. But few probably appreciate the immense difficulties which a Western nation encounters in governing the Oriental, differing as he does so essentially in race, religion, tradition, and ideals. After all is said and done, it appears to us that Egypt has little to complain of, and that any intermeddling with the work of those who are thoroughly acquainted with the local circumstances, and are acting to the best of their ability in the true interests of the local Government, would be fraught with incalculably distasterous results to the country.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt. Col. C. J. Markham and officers, the band of the 1st Batt. King's Royal Rifles will perform the following selection of music from 4 to 6 p.m. on the terrace at the Grand Continental to-morrow (Thursday):-
1. March-Cornelius-Mendelssohn.
2. Overture-Rosamunde-Sohubert.
3. Cornet Solo-Serenata-Braga. (Soloist Corpl. Styler)
4. Selection- The Belle of New York-Kerker.
5. Waltz-Love and Life in Vienna-Komzak.
6. Piccolo Solo-The Lark's Festival-Brewer. (Soloist Corpl. H. Arnold)
7. Selection-Carmen-Bizet.
8. Intermezzo Cake Walk-Ramona-Johnsen.
Regimental March. Khedivial Anthem. God Save the King. Thomas Brown, Bandmaster.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Brindisi Mail.
The mail from Brindisi, vià Port Said, will arrive at Alexandria this afternoon and be distributed at the G. P. O. at 4.45 p.m.
The Fitzner Quartette.
This celebrated Viennese quartette gave a charming concert last night at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria.
Port Sudan Mosque.
A member of the Legislative Council, Chawarbi Pacha, has under taken to pay for the cost of erecting a mosque at Port Sudan.
The Fayoum Circle.
The Ministry of Public Works has issued a notice creating a new irrigation circle for the Fayoum. Hussein Bey Wassif has been appointed inspector of this circle.
King's Mussulman Orderlies.
It has been decided, according to the Exchange Telegraph Company, that the four native orderlies to the King to be sent home from India this year shall be Mussulmans.
Imports of Coal.

The imports of coal from January 1 to 25 amounted to 52,670 tons, as compared with 22,368 tons last year. This month Wales alone has sent 33,941 tons, Newcastle 7,978, the Scotch districts 2,726, and Yorkshire 7,275.
New British Club.

We are requested to state that the opening of the British Club has been unavoidably postponed until Saturday next, 3rd inst, when it is hoped that the decoration of the premises will be completed and members will attend.
Union Artistique Française.

The Union Artistique Française will hold a reception in their rooms to-night at 9, for Mme. Moreno and M. Monteux, of the French comedy company. In their honour, and with their assistance, they have organised a soirée, to which the members are invited.
Zagazig Municipality.

A complaint having been made to the Ministry of the Interior by a number of Zagazig notables against the election to the Municipality of that town of one of the members of the Legislative Council, resident in Cairo, the Ministry sent Mr. Melville to Zagazig to enquire into these statements and their accuracy has now been verified.
Mohamedan Almanac.

An almanac for the year 1324 of the Hegira has just been issued. This useful little almanac, which is published annually by G. Abul Wafa, superintendent of Kom el Nadoura Observatory, contains a companion with the Gregorian and Coptic dates, and has besides a large amount of useful information. We understand that 5,000 copies have been presented to the Moslem benevolent society presided over by Khalil Pacha Hamdy.
Savoy Hotel.

The weekly small dances which are held at the Savoy Hotel on Saturday evenings have been so popular and well attended that the management have decided to hold one every Tuesday in addition to the Saturday one. The first of these extra dances was well held last night, when, though the attendance was not up to the average, as it is not yet generally known that the Tuesday evening dances have been started, a most enjoyable time was spent.
Scientific Burglar.
A few days ago a determined attempt at burglary was made at Mit Haway in the Santa
district. El Saied Effendi Nasr is a man of means, who it is believed is in the habit of keeping large sums of money at his house. Three burglars determined to see whether

they could get possession of this and tried to effect an entry by making a hole in the wall. Nasr Effendi heard them and fired, killing one of the men on the spot. The ghaffirs, hearing the report of firearms, came up and opened fire. The two survivors had to capitulate and were arrested. These miscreants were found to be burglars of a type new in the province. They had revolvers of an up-to-date American pattern and twenty different keys of the skeleton type and other sorts.

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: KING CHRISTIAN'S DEATH.
PERIOD OF COURT MOURNING
(Gazette’s Special Service)
London, Wednesday, Jan. 31.

The Court will go into mourning for six weeks in consequence of the death of King Christian. Ladies will go into half mourning after March 1. So far the following personages have intimated their intention of attending the funeral of the deceased monarch : Emperor William, the Grand Duke Michael Nicholavitch, representing the Tsar, King George of Greece, King Haakon of Norway, and the Archduke Frederick of Austria.
ARMY REFORM.
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Wednesday, Jan. 31.
A new office has been created of Inspector General of Supplies, Army Service Corps.
It is stated that the re-arming of the Artillery is proceeding rapidly and will be competed in 1907.
THE LATE SIR ELWIN PALMER

The funeral of the late Sir Elwin Palmer took place very quietly yesterday afternoon The body was conveyed to the cemetery on a gun carriage and there interred in the presence of the members of the family and a very few intimate friends.
A TRIBUTE.

A Cairo correspondent writes : The local Press has paid its just tribute to the man who played to prominent a part in the work of reform in Egypt in past days ; the untiring worker, the gifted financial administrator. The tributes offered here if not to Sir Elwin Palmer, the official, the financier, the keen sighted man of business, but it is offered by one who knew him well, to the gentle-natured man who will be laid to rest unostentatiously in the cemetery of Old Cairo this afternoon. His unselfishness, his ready sympathy, his generous helpfulness to those less fortunate than himself, his love for children, these and many another endearing human trait will keep the memory of Sir Elwin Palmer green in the hearts of those who knew him, long after his successful administration and financial achievements have been forgotten.
NATIONAL HOTELS AND RESIDENCES CO.

The board of this company has decided upon erecting an annexe to their new hotel in the Sharia Soliman Pacha, Cairo, as although only opened about three months, the management of the hotel are getting more applications for rooms than they can satisfy, and last week every bed was occupied. It is now intended to build a new block at the back of and communicating with the main building which will add about another 150 rooms, bringing the total up to 300 for next season, and the work will be commenced next May. Mr. Bauer, the courteous and indefatigable manager, is to be congratulated upon the success he has already achieved in so short a time.
CAIRO LAND DEAL

The plot of laid, nearly 1,300 metres in extent with building on it, facing the entrance to the Mousky street, alongside of the Cairo Mixed Tribunals, and formerly known as the old Zepitah, has just been purchased by Suliman Bev Dessouki from the Société Immobilière- d’Egypte for LE 72,000, which works out at over LE 55 the square metre. The Société Immobilière d’Egypte bought the property about six years ago from M. Moise Cattani for LE 25,000 and spent about LE 13,000 in adding to the then existing building.

Ths property in question is not unknown to British residents, as it houses the well-known drapery establishment "Àu Dé Rouge." We understand that, in making a fresh contract with the new proprietor, Mr. Plunkett has arranged to again enlarge his premises, which will enable him to add to his already well aborted stock.
ABBASSIEH OASES
The Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oases Company, which has been formed to create oases in the desert of Abbassieh, is

about to extend the tramway line from the Ataba el Khadra square, Cairo, to Abbassieh, as far as the first oasis which it is intended to establish a little beyond the barracks, on an elevation which dominates the whole of the city of Cairo. The panorama to be seen from this spot is splendid. One finds oneself on a high plateau, thirty metres above Cairo, whose domes and minarets are to be seen standing against the horizon. Further on is the valley of the Nile, then the Pyramids, whose profiles stand out clear against the clear blue sky. The company will shortly build in the first oasis a hotel of 200 rooms and a hundred or so villas, which it will let out at rentals varying from P.T. 300 to P.T. 1,000 a month, according to size and position.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Seti sailed hence yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,600 bales cotton.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed yesterday afternoon from Liverpool and is due here about the 13th promo. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: VISIT TO OMDURMAM.
div.p: YESTERDAY’S DOING.
BALL AT KHARTOUM PALACE.
(From our Special Correspondent).
Khartoum, Wednesday, 11 25 a.m.

The members of the Legislative Council and the Press correspondents “paid a visit to Omdurman yesterday and were shown over the battlefields and other objects of interest by Sir Rudolf von Slatin Pacha, Inspector-General of the Sudan, Bimbashi Amery. Intelligence Officer, Bimbashis Lewin and Young. In the afternoon a visit was paid to the office of the ‘Sudan Gazette,’ where the guests were entertained to tea by Mr. Tabet, the editor. The members of the Legislative Council stayed to have lunch at Omdurman with the chief of the merchants, Hassan Bey.

In the evening a "soirée daubante" followed the dinner given at the Palace in honour of Lord Cromer, who was present with the whole of his party, including the Sudan officers and officials who returned with him from Port Sudan. Among those present were Sir Vincent Corbett, Sir Rudolf von Slatin, Colonel McCracken, Mr. Dupuis, Inspector General. Sudan Irrigation Service ; Mr. Bonham Carter, Legal Secretary ; Colonel Bernard, Financial Secretary ; Colonel Macaulay, RE, Director of Railways ; Mr. Carrie, Director of Education, Major Phipps, Civil Secretary ; Commander Bond, Director of Steamers and Boats ; Major Stack, Military and Private Secretary, Mr. Bonns, Director of Agriculture and Lands ; Mr. Hodgson, Mr. Higgins, Mr. Bowden-Smith, Dr. Christopherson, Acting Director, Sudan Medical Department ; Captain Charlton, Assistant Military Secretary; Captain Vaughan, Assistant Private Secretary, Captain Collins, A.D.C., Kaimakam Stanton Bey, Bimbashi Owen, the members of the Legislative Council, all the high officials and heads of departments, the chief British and native army officers, the officers of the Berks detachment, etc. The ladies present were Lady Wingate and Mesdames de Halpert, Bernard, Stanton, Asser, Page, McCracken, Brown, More, Balfour, Shukair, Stack and Gamble, the Misses Wilson, Danford, and Bewley, Mrs. Feetham, and Mrs. Harvey.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
div.p: The vernacular Moslem Press do not regard the inauguration of the Nile-Red Sea railway with any degree of satisfaction. In regard to last Saturday’s ceremony, “Al Zaher remarks : “We must entitle that day the

day of Egypt’s funeral, and we are right in so characterising it. Thereby Egypt’s commercial relations with the Sudan have been severed and we have been deprived of that country. The little hopes we entertained have now been dissipated, while on the other hand England exalted in triumph. The Sudan

gives life to Egypt, and when the former country fell, into the hands of a powerful Government, the only alternative for Egypt is a miserable submission. Egypt will be afflicted, for a great deal of the waters of the Nile

will be taken to feed the canals of the Sudan, and Egypt thereby will suffer from lack of water. It was with Egypt’s blood and Egypt’s wealth that the Sudan was conquered and now England has come to reap the fruits of our victories. In the hands of the English the Sudan will be like a dagger held at the heart of Egypt. Now that the new railway has been opened a new route

will be created for the Sudan, and if one day Egypt becomes strong enough to demand back its rights, this route will enable England to invade our country and put an end to all attempts to recover our liberties. Therefore we denominate the 27th of January, 1906, as the day of Egypt's funeral.
“Al Moayad” states that everything tends to show that the Sudan is to be turned into a British Colony.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND RAMLEH RAILWAY.
div.p: The company’s financial year closed on the 30th September last and the report shows that the results have been highly satisfactory. The receipts have increased by P.T. 300,506. This is excellent, especially in view of the redaction in the tarif. The total number of passengers was 1,494,891, which speaks volumes for

the growth of the eastern suburbs of Alexandria. The cost of the year’s working was P.T. 3 360,957, as against PT. 2,931,720 in the preceding year. div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: SIGNS OF THE TIMES.
“CHANGE HERE FOR KHARTOUM ”
(From our Correspondent).
Suakin (via Atbara), January 19.

The Greek steamer Alexandria, of the Hadji Daocd Company, arrived here from Suez on the 10th inst, and went alongside pier No. 1, where she discharged into railway tracks a consignment of timber for Messrs. Griva Brothers at Khartoum. This is noteworthy from the fact that it is the first consignment of merchandise to be sent to Khartoum via Suakin by rail.

The Khedivial mail steamer Mahallah (Captain Williams) arrived from Suez on the 14th inst. and also went alongside pier No. 1, where she discharged railway material and bridges that wars transhipped at Suez for the Sudan Government Railways. The Mahallah also landed a beautiful pair of Russian horses to be conveyed to Jeddah for General of the Hedjaz by the S.S. Missir, which left here yesterday for Jeddah with a large number of Sudanem pilgrims.
The Suakin District Office moved to Port Sudan on the 17th inst., and will remain there until the 17th inst.
A guard of honour, furnished by the 6th Battalion, E.A., will leave for Port Sudan tomorrow by special train, to be present at the reception of Lord Cromer.
The first goods train, composed of 18 railway tracks of gum for export, arrived here from Khartoum on the 16th inst., and the goods are now waiting here to be shipped by a special steamer.
DEATH OF MR BARRON
(From our Correspondent.)
Khartoum, Wednesday, 10 a.m.
I regret to announce the death of Mr. T. Barron, the distinguished geological surveyor to the Sudan Government. He succumbed to a severe attack of dysentery at El Koweit.

Mr. Barron formerly belonged to the Egyptian Survey Department of the Public Works Ministry at Cairo, where he did some excellent work in revising the geology of the country between Cairo and Suez. In 1904 Mr. Barron was placed at the disposal of the Sudan Government for the greater part of the year for work in that area, where, among other things, he examined the lignite deposits of Tobelga in North West Abyssinia, and subsequently definitely joined the Sudan service.
KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
LA TOSCA.
La Tosca was given for the second time on
Saturday night. The chief interest centered round

Signor Polese and Signora Bellincioni. Signor Polese we saw last year, and his performance was as good as ever as the chief of police, in look, voice, and gesture. Signora Bellincioni we had to contrast with last year’s exponent, Signora Pandulfini. The latter somehow seems to convey the part more accurately, as the Italian who can rise to the height of passion, and kill, relentless, the persecutor of her lover ; she accepted the murder, scared for the moment at herself, then prepared for all consequences. In the last act, knowing the execution to be a farce, she even applauded the lifelike fall of her lover to the ground after the fatal volley. It was a memorable touch, and somehow more convincing. In Signora Bellincioni's interpretation no detail is missed, even the terror which makes her actually drop the crucifix on the man’s breast : but it is the presentment of a loving and timorous woman, who cannot bear to face even the fictitious execution of her lover ; and so it does not seem to fit in with the part. But perhaps this is rather a personal criticism. What we would desire to point out is the flagrant failure of certain minor details, as against their last year's success and principally the part Of the Shirro. Last year this was taken by one of the 3rd tenors, who had a pleasing if small voice, who acted quietly, and who “looked” the part. This year it was given to Signor Vincenso, a “utility” tenor : he transformed it into sheer low comedy and not only spoilt the part, but introduced a jarring element into the rest of the scenes in which he took part. This was needless. Signor Vincenso has some sort of part every night and need not take these occasions to make himself remarkable or notorious at the expense of other and better performers : it does not enhance his credit, and it injures his colleagues. For the rest, the orchestra was good, but Maestro Zuccani is hard on his singers : to keep pace with his orchestral effects they must strain their voices. As we know him to be a good conductor, he surely need not search for high effect in La Tosca, of all music- La Tosca, part of which, as an overture or intermezzo, have even secured “encores” at the Nouveautes Theatre. A conductor who humours and does not drown his voices may escape the notice of a Cairo audience but he should gain in his own estimation, not to mention that a few “cognoscenti” who may be present. Details like this count for so much in minor opera that we hope they may be less casually and callously carried out in future performances.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers will hold its next meeting under the presidency of the Khedive after the Beyram holidays.

div.head: SHEPHEARD’S BALL.
SUCCESSFUL COTILLON.
FIRST BIG BALL OF THE SEASON-
div.p: It is difficult enough to find words to describe the animated scene of the crowded ballroom at Shepheard’s Hotel on Monday night, when nigh upon eight hundred people gathered together to enjoy the first big ball of the Cairo season. Congratulations are due to the indefatigable endeavours of Mr. Schaetzler and his staff both for the beauty of the decorations, the excellence the buffet, and also for the highly successful cotillon, which was the event of the evening and which will remain as a pleasing memory for many months in the minds of those who were present. The huge dining-room, which serves on such occasions as the ballroom, is significantly proportioned and decorated at any time, but never does it look finer than when it is filled with dancers, ornamented with festoons and garlands of greenery all ablaze with tiny lights. In spite of the dance given by M. Causai Bey in honour of his son’s marriage the same night, the crowd at Shepheard’s was at times so great that dancing became almost impossible. The cotillon commenced about midnight and no abler master of ceremonies could be found than Dr. Armstrong, to whose energy and genial leadership its success was due. At a given signal he and bis partner Mrs. Neve took their places the ballroom, and quickly a gay and never-ending string of ladies and their partners followed in his wake in procession round the room and through the adjoining drawing room. When they re-appeared each lady was wearing some quaint and bewitching headdress, and each cavalier also wore either a rakish and much decorated white top hat, or else a crooked hat of formidable dimensions. A short waltz followed, and then the procession started off afresh, this time returning with other favours, and so the different figures till every energetic individual was decked out with furious headgear, fluffy paper scarves settle flags, tinsel orders, etc., and carried in their hands ornamented batons, musical instruments, sunshades, or flattering pennons. Perhaps it was the fancy garb which lent such a carnival air to the scene, and certainly everybody seemed infected with a spirit of joyousness and merry-making not always to be found in the ordinary ballroom. Borne very amusing figures brought together strange and unexpected partners; in one the gentlemen were guided only in their choice by the toes of the ladies' slippers as they showed beneath an outstretched sheet, and in another the ladies gazed into mirrors aqd accepted or rejected the reflection of their swains aa they passed in line behind them. With much merriment and laughter the cotillon proceeded till about one o’clock, when a beautifully decorated little gondola appeared in the hall laden with floral favours and lit with strings of candles, and as it was drawn round the room it was surrounded by an eager and bedizened crowd all anxious to receive one last memento to add to their store of favours.

To give a complete list of those present is beyond our poor endeavours, but the following are a few of those who were noticed during the evening. Perhaps few beyond those staying in the hotel were aware that the Duke and Duchess of Madrid were among those taking a keen interest in the proceedings, General de Medina, who is A.D.C. to Don Carlos, being in attendance. The Prince of Henan was also there, and Count Bismarck Bohlen, as well as Count Arnim. The Count and Countess Lerche across from Ghenreh Palace Hotel, and Baron Gleichenstein and Baron Pogrell were mixing in the throng. Signora Bellincioni the prima donna of the present opera season, was noticed during the earlier hours of the evening, and Signor Serato, the well-known violinist, found sufficient inducement to keep him these till the very end. Mrs. Carton de Wiart spent a short time in the ball-room among her many friends, and Mr. and Mrs. Montagu Summers were among those who had entertained their friends at dinner previous to the bell. Amongst the well known folk staying in the hotel were General and Mrs. Pitzhughes, Major General Gillespie, Mr. and Mrs. W. Johnstone, Mr. and Mrs. Kling, Mr. and Mrs. Pitch and the Misses Pitch, Mr. and Mrs. Dodge, Mr. and Mrs. Berry Wall, Mrs. and Miss Hurst, Miss Wilkin, Mr. and Mrs. Warden, Mrs. Montgomery, and Mr. and Mrs. Skinner. div.p: Our Special Correspondent at Khartoum telegraphs that the Archduke and Archduchess Otto of Austria are staying incognito at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum, under the names of the Count and Countess de la Sala.

The hall which was given by M. and Mme. Moise Cattani Bey on Monday in honour of the marriage of their son to Mlle. Moseéri, which will take place to-morrow, was attended by a great many people. The ballroom and drawing rooms had been very tastefully decorated end were thronged until the early hours of the morning by dancers and onlookers. div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: LORD CROMER’S RESOLVE
EULOGIUMS OF LONDON PRESS.
London, January 30.

The “Standard,” in a leading article, declares that Lord Cromer’s resolve to remain in Egypt is the surest guarantee that the develop meet of the Sudan will proceed uninterruptedly. The “Morning Post” says that Egypt presents a rare example of administration influenced solely by a desire to benefit the inhabitants regardless of the vicissitudes of party. The ‘Daily Telegraph’ refers to Lord Cromer as one of the most practical of the strong men who ever wielded the proconsular sceptre of Great Britain. ( Reuter )
KING CHRISTIAN’S DEATH
HIS LAST MOMENTS.
Copenhagen, January 30.

It was not till 2 30 that the King felt sufficiently indisposed to retire to bed. Only the Dowager Empress of Russia and Prince Hana were present at the end. The other members of the family arrived too late. The official announcement of the King’s death says that the symptoms pointed to heart failure. The accession of Frederick VIII. will be proclaimed to-morrow morning at the Amalienborg palace in the presence of the high dignitaries, and also at a joint meeting of both houses of the Rigadag as well as in public before the Royal Palace.
(Reuter)
Berlin, January 30.
The Emperor will go to Copenhagen. (R.)
London, January 30.
The Queen will go to Copenhagen, but whether the King will go or not will depend on the date of the funeral. (Reuter.)
OPENING OF PARLIAMENT
London, January 30.
The King will open Parliament with modified ceremonial. (Reuter)
SPANISH ROYAL MARRIAGE.
TRIBUTE TO PRINCESS ENA.
Madrid, January 30.

The Press pays its tribute to the physical and intellectual attainments of Princess Ena of Battenberg. It hopes that the marriage will infuse sweetness into the bitterness of Spanish national life. [Reuter)
JEWISH COLONY IN THE EMPIRE.
LORD ELGIN’S SUPPORT.
London, January 30.
Lord Elgin has written to Dr. Zangwill promising the most careful and sympathetic attention to any scheme for the planting of a Jewish colony in some unoccupied part of the Empire. (Reuter)
NEW GREEK CABINET
ITS PROGRAMME.
Athens, January 30.

M. Thsotokis has announced the programme of the new Greek Cabinet to the Chamber. Large administrative reforms are included the redaction of military service to one year, and the reduction of the effective army by half daring peace. The resulting economies will be devoted to the increase of armaments.
(Reuter)
RUSSIAN GENERAL KILLED.
Tiflis, January 30.
General Griaznoff, Chief of Staff of the Viceroy, has been killed by a bomb. (Reuter)

div.head: FOOTBALL
ST ANDREW F. C. v. EASTERN TELEGRAPH F. C.
div.p: St. Andrew’s are to be congratulated on the victory which they achieved over the E. T. C. F. C. on Saturday afternoon. Few—unless they be thorough bigots—will grudge the Moharrem Bey team the success. From a playing point of view the game was one of the most enjoyable played by either of the teams this season. There was no foul play to speak of. Combination was not by any means very pronounced but at the same time there were several brilliant bits of play from individual members on both sides. The E. T. C. men were the first to settle down, and when they rattled on couple of goals in the first fifteen minutes things were looking bright indeed for them. The first goal secured was a smartly executed piece of play, and Blythman made no mistake in driving McLean's cross shot home The second goal was equally well taken by Ingleton after a scrimmage near Curtis. The E. T. C. exhibited the better front of the two teams, only to be superseded by the Saints at a later stage of the game. Saints made several attempts to reduce the leeway before the interval, but Dowson was in good form and cleared cleverly. Halftime arrived with the score : E. T. C. 2; St Andrew’s 0.

From the restart the E. T. C. were again first to settle down, and a couple of corners were forced in rapid succession. Oliver cleared when things were looking dangerous and from that point the Saints took the game in hand. Their first goal came from the foot of Lark, who took up a neat pass from Clark and beat Dowson all the way. Saints again returned to the attack and forced a corner. This was well placed by Bright, but Dowson fisted out. Oliver here got possession and put his side equal with a rocket shot. This success inspired the Saints, and the B. T. C defence seemed to lose their heads. Constantinidis and Clark had no difficulty in getting round Sedgwick, but Lees was more steady and recovered well. The play of the home right wing in this half was the feature of the game, the ball being taken down the field between them again and again. The shot that won the goal for the Saints was one of that order seldom seen outside of first class football circles, Constantinidis taking the ball well down the touch line and putting into goal almost from the corner flag. Dowson just got his fingers on it, but failed to keep it out of the net and the Saints that stood one up. A little later the same player had hard lines in not repeating the performance, his shot coming right across the goal mouth. Curtis during this half had been practically a passenger, but he had one shot to deal with sent in from near midfield by Shepherd. It was a high dropping shot, and looked like sneaking under the bar into the net, but Curtis got there in time and touched over. The revolting corner was fruitless.

All the goals of the match were nested in the same goal. Both goal keepers were unfortunate in losing goals they did but all were of the unsaveable order, the Saints’ winning goal more particularly. Dowson had many tough shots to negotiate during the progress of the game, and despite the goals lost, he came through the test creditably.

The E. T. C .team felt Byrne’s absence at centre forward. Sedgwick, too, although a capable back, is hardly to be compared with Willmott. Lees played a sound game until the Saints took the lead ,then he became somewhat flukey in his clearing. McLean was prominent on the visitors left, but Rofe and Keill gave him very little rope. The first goal of the match, however, was entirely due to McLean. All the halves were prominent, and Henley and Blythman combined with good effect.

For the homesters, Clark and Constantinidis were particularly prominent, and deserved more success than they got. Lark’s play at centre was also good, but there were times when he had hardly sufficient way on the ball to get it out to the wings. Cowie and Keill at back took a lot of beating.
The following were the teams:—
E.T.C. —Dowson, Lees, Sedgwick, Townsend, Shepherd, Colder, Blythman, Henley, Ingleton, Ash, and McLean.
St. Andrews. Curtis, Keill, Cowie, Rofe, Oliver, Bright, Constantinidis, Clark, Lark, Jones, and Tulloch.
Referee. —Mr. P. Byrne.

div.head: EGYPTIAN REFORM.
PRINCESS NAZLI’S OPINION.
div.p: In our issue Saturday last we translated a severe criticism of the Prinness Nazli Haneu which appeared in the Arabic newspaper “A Zaher,” because she had declared that the Egyptians were babies and that Lord Cromer “did everything.” A few days ago the Princess was interviewed by Dr. Nimr, editor of “Al Mokattam,” who asked her whether it was true that her highness had adopted the French nationality, and the Princess made the following statement in answer:

“I am well known to be an Ottoman subject and so will I remain as long as I live. I have no desire to change my nationality. Had you called at the Cairo Government and seen the passport I took last year as an Ottoman subject you would have easily seen that I had not changed my original nationality. At for my husband, Sayid Khalil Abou Hadjil, he is a Tunisian under French projection, nothing more. I know you have put this question to me because you saw in “Al Zaher,” a few days ago, some tale of the kind ; and I am pleased to be the first person alluded to in that paper among those whose remarks were published by M. de Guerville in his book “New Egypt.” I do not deny that “A1 Zaher” has translated my words very correctly ; but had its editor been personally acquainted with Lord Cromer and known his noble qualities, his straightforwardness, and his justice as I know them, the editor would have confirmed my words Lord Cromer has acted alone in Egypt without anybody to help him, and his most important and useful acts were all based on his own sound wisdom and energy. If, however, any blunder has occurred in the reforms which have been executed up to date for the welfare of this country the same errors would have been made by us, Egyptians, and he is not to be blamed. This is the truth, the whole truth, which must be given utterance to at any cost. Those who are acquainted with Lord Cromer know what sort of a man he is. He dislikes flattery and flatterers, and does not care a bit for personal interests, but all his attention is given to the common weal. Lord Cromer has served his country straightforwardly and has treated Egypt carefully and uprightly during his very distinguished career. This precious freedom which our Press and our nation in general enjoy, this prosperity, this good order in everything, and all the other improvements have been brought about by Lord Cromer and we are indebted to him therefore.

“Is it a rule that if any one of as should speak the troth, he should adopt another nationality? Is it not our duty to say the truth cost it what it may? I am not accustomed to make use of flattery to anybody, and it is my temparament to loath perversity. Truth is a fire that burns only in those who do not use it while it has a bright light which is as necessary to our souls as life is to all creatures. When we compare the present with the past, we much regret what we have lost. In former days there was neither justice nor progress in our country such as there are at present. But even then it was our fault for reflecting our forefathers’ works, little caring to preserve what they had established for us. The memory brings back the past but there is no need now to reneat what is so well known. My late father was the most noble and high spirited man of his time, and he deserved every good, yet his estate, 85,000 feddans was 1st through no fault of his nor through any crime committed by us. Had I observed that we now are able to improve the State by great undertakings and the good conduct of public business, I would have been very proud of our ability and would have opposed all who declared the reverse. But any one who loves his country must confess the obvious truth and not love his fatherland blindly, and be unwilling to understand the results. If any one thinks that I talked ill of Egypt, God protect us from such an erroreous person for he must he unable to understand the purport of my words. How can that be?

Am I not a daughter of Egypt? How then do I want to abuse my country people? If any one imagines that I have talked about Egypt for some personal motives, let that man enquire into my motives and he will know that I want nothing for myself. All that I have ever craved of Lord Cromer was for the sake of some Egyptians and I do not see that it will be a difficult matter to mention their names if this should serve any useful purpose in the present case.
What is Whisky ?
“Sandy Macdonald” 10 YEARS OLD
IS THE Finest Matured Malt WHISKY.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The 1st Battalion Royal lnniskilling Fusiliers will proceed from Belfast to Malta in the coming trooping season of 1906-07. It will be replaced at Belfast by the 1st Battalion Rifle Brigade now at Malta.
Second Lieutenant C. C. Hewitt, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Cairo, has been promoted lieutenant. He gets his second star after three years and three months service.

Second Lieutenent S. B. Duffin, a Tyrone gentleman recently appointed to the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers from the Royal South Downs, has been ordered to join the 2nd Battalion of the Inniskillings at Cairo and will proceed there with the draft which the 1st Battalion is preparing.
Major A. J. B. Addison, Royal Irish Rifles, on absorption, has been posted to the 1st Battalion at Meerut, Bengal, where he will join next month.

Lieutenant G. F. Pridham, 1st Battalion Welsh Regiment, has been selected for service with the Khedive’s Army. He is a smart young subaltern of seven years service and in the usual course he should shortly be promoted captain. He served with the “Men of Harlech” in the South African War, for which he holds the medal with five clasps.

It is stated that the regiments of Imperial Yeomanry, of which there are 56 in the United Kingdom, will be subjected to a rigid medical inspection whilst in camp in the coming drill season. This will be for the purpose of weeding out the physically unfit, and men who are over the maximum age. It is stated that the Treasury has objections to paying men who are not fit to serve the country. It may be remembered that a similar order last drill season caused “ructions” amongst several volunteer battalions.

The Army Council has notified that arrangements for this year’s practice of Royal Garrison Artillery units other than heavy Batteries and Siege Train Companies (including Royal Garrison Artillery Militia) are to be made locally and that instructions to that effect will be included in the general programme for gun practice, 1906, which, when ready, will be issued to all concerned. Great importance is attached to all practice being performed under as near an approach to war conditions as possible, and in all commands in which light quickfiring guns are mounted for anti-torpedo boat defences and where the local conditions
admit of night practice from them, attention is to be given to this subject. A large proportion of the ammunition allowed these guns is to be utilised, where possible, for such practice.

Much harm has undoubtedly been done to the cause of the Army by the writings of Captain Mahan, says a writer in the “United Service Magazine.” Captain Mayan, in his interesting works, has approached from the question from the naval point of view, and it has not made it clear that in all cases the relative importance of a victory at sea has depended on whether the fleet has had an army behind it. Obviously sea power, as a strategical asset, loses much of its importance, unless it is reckoned in conjunction with the other military resources of the State concerned, and if there are no such other resources, it becomes a mere preventive of invasion. In other words, a naval war can never become an offensive war, where land operations are in question, unless the maritime nation waging the war has a disposable army capable of prosecuting the war on land. A great fuss was and is made over the battle of the Nile. But the fruits of that battle were not fully reaped until a British force had been landed in Aboukir Bay to remove the French from Egypt. The Navy is praised, but the Army is forgotten, although it was by the latter that the campaign was completed.

The first class cruiser Hawke, Captain F. S. Miller, arrived at Sheerness on Tuesday last, from a cruise in Spanish waters, and is coaling preparatory to leaving England for the West Indies to rejoin the Fourth Cruiser Squadron. The cruisers Edgar and St George are to be ready to assemble off the Eddystone at the end of the month for a cruise in the West Indies, to rejoin the Fourth Cruiser Squadron.
The wooden battleship Caledonia, Commander J. F. E. Green, which has been attached to the Nora command for the past 14 years for service as a training ship for boys, was

paid out of commission at Queensferry on Friday, and placed on the sale list, the boys who were training on her having been transferred to the shore establishments at Shotely. The disposal of the Caledonia, which was known as the Impregnable in the earlier years of her service, will remove one of the few remaining links connecting the Service with the days when "wooden walls” constituted the first line of defence.

div.head: A VETERAN OF THE BUCK HAWK. MEXICAN AND THE CIVIL WARS.
div.p: CAPT. W. W. JACKSON.
Sufferings Were Protracted and Severe — Tried Every Known Remedy Without Relief — Serious Stomach Trouble Cured by Three Bottles of Peruna!
Capt. W. W. Jackson, 705 G St., N. W., Washington, D. C., writes :
“I am eighty-three years old, a veteran of the Black Hawk, Mexican and the Civil Wars. I am by profession a physician, but abandoned the same.
“Some years ago I was seriously affected with catarrh of the stomach. My sufferings were protracted and severe. I tried every known remedy without obtaining relief.
“In desperation I began the use of your Peruna. I began to realise immediate though gradual improvement.
“After the use of three bottles every appearance of my complaint was removed, and I have no hesitation in recommending it as an infallible remedy for that disorder.”
—W. W. Jackson.
Address Dr. S. B. Hartman, President of The Hartman Sanitarium, Columbus, Ohio.

For special directions everyone should read ‘The Ills of Life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and pruggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings. Those wishing direct correspondence with Dr. Hartman and can wait the necessary delay in receiving a reply should address Dr. S. B. Hartmen, Columbus, Ohio, U.S.A.
